learning_outcomes.description: Analyse and evaluate the integration of physiological systems in the regulation of essential functions
Analyse and evaluate the role of dysfunction as a cause of disease and the consequences of disease on multiple systems
Apply skills in recognition of pathological changes in the structure of cells and tissues
Apply skills in written and oral scientific communication, including comprehension and critical review of research articles.
Evaluate and apply practical skills in the analysis, interpretation and presentation of scientific data

assessments.assessment_title: Pathophysiology of Disease Series: Presentation slides
assessments.task_description:
The assessment component is required for the following Pathophysiology of Disease Series: Oral Presentation assessment.

Students will research and present on the pathophysiology of a disease of their choice (not covered by the lectures). Each presentation should include the known cause(s), pathophysiology, influences from other systems studied in the course (if relevant), current treatments, and an example of current cutting edge research in the disease or treatment. Students will be exposed to a diverse range of pathophysiological changes, their causes and treatment strategies. Further details of the assessment format and marking criteria will be provided on Blackboard during the semester.

Students are required to submit their presentation slides for the Oral presentation to Turnitin. Upon submission of the Presentation Slides, you should check in the Turnitin Assignment Inbox page that your report was submitted successfully.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your Assessment task, with the electronic coversheet available on the School's website, to Turnitin by the submission deadline. You may submit drafts to Turnitin up to the due date, but you will only be able to submit once on or after the due date. You should also keep an electronic copy of every piece of assessment you submit.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

They will then choose one disease (different from their presentation topic) and assess how its anatomical changes relate to pathophysiology, focusing on tissues covered in BIOM3015 or other organs of interest. After completing the worksheet, students must prepare a final assessment report.

learning_activities.topic:
Integrated Pathology Learning Centre Assignment

You will visit UQ’s Integrated Pathology Learning Centre (IPLC) at the Royal Brisbane and Women’s Hospital Campus (Herston). The IPLC is a human pathology museum including just over 5000 preserved human pathology specimens and an incredible educational resource library for trainee biomedical scientists. Further details about the IPLC can be found here https://biomedical- sciences.uq.edu.au/facilities/integrated-pathology-learning-centre

Assessment Report: Following completion of this worksheet, you are required to complete an assessment report on one of these organ disease states. In this report you

must address the following:

(1) Give a brief description of the anatomy and typical physiology of the organ and body system chosen. You may like to include a sketch/schematic (200 words)

(2) Describe the anatomy of the abnormal specimen examined in the IPLC (100 words)

(3) Explain the pathophysiology of the disease state examined in relation to the anatomical features observed (200 words)

(4) Detail how disease pathophysiology in this organ might influence other body systems (300 words)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct .To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI tools.
